terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Balkan mountains. Significant elevation with mountain scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional Balkan event. Mountainous terrain with moderate organization and regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: Balkan Gravel is a regional event in Slovenia/Croatia—mountainous terrain with significant elevation. The Balkan mountains are scenic, but the moderate organization and regional field keep it firmly in Tier 3.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A scenic Balkan mountain gravel race. Worth it for Balkan/European cyclists. Not a destination race for international travelers.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in Balkans/Europe—yes, it's solid. If you're international—there are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For similar mountain terrain: Carpathian Gravel, Greek Gravel.

logistics.airport: Ljubljana (LJU) or Zagreb (ZAG) depending on location
logistics.food: Slovenia/Croatia has full dining options. Stock nutrition.

logistics.explanation: Martin Moschek planned "6 days for the route" but kept "a maximum of 9 days at my disposal" because he didn't "know the area or all the challenges." Cross-border Slovenia/Croatia adds passport complexity, and Golo notes route planning difficulties since "maps do not allow reliable conclusions about road condition."

length.explanation: At 65 miles, this sits in the sweet spot for a day race rather than the region's multi-day epics. Golo's recreational touring pace averaged 68-113km daily over 8 days on longer Balkan routes, suggesting this distance allows racing hard without survival logistics. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: Golo describes terrain that "offered everything from perfect asphalt to washboard to coarse gravel." The surface mix emphasizes grinding over technical skills - Martin Moschek's Komoot data shows 81.5km natural surface and 322km loose surface across similar Balkan routes. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: 4500 feet across 65 miles delivers solid climbing without the sadistic ratios of longer Balkan events. Martin Moschek notes regional routes average "2,000 metres of elevation gain per 100 km" - this falls well below that punishing standard while still separating climbers. Similar elevation profile to Gravel Worlds.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 67°F and lows of 49°F, with a 65% chance of rain on any given day. Golo experienced "a heavy rain shower" and "problematic weather" requiring route changes during his June ride. The Slovenia/Croatia border region serves up variety - riders plan for rain contingencies and temperature swings without extreme conditions. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL.

altitude.explanation: Golo hit "the highest point at almost 900m altitude" through Kozana National Park on similar regional routes. The 1180m Karaula Pass represents typical elevations - enough climbing to matter without approaching high-altitude territory. Modest altitude compared to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

adventure.explanation: Golo describes riding "through completely uninhabited territory" where "before the war there were a few places of which only ruins remain - now there is only nature and lots of it." Cross-border racing through karstic landscapes delivers adventure beyond typical gravel fare.

prestige.explanation: The field includes elite names like Leanne Bentley and Benedek Borsos, but this appears connected to the longer Trans Balkan Race rather than establishing independent prestige. Regional Balkan events are growing but lack the international recognition of established European races.

race_quality.explanation: With 160 riders signed up for related regional events, there's organizational infrastructure, but specific details for this 65-mile format remain unclear. The longer Trans Balkan Race provides proven course management through challenging terrain.

experience.explanation: Tenul found locals "very friendly" and managed communication "quite well without English or German" with mountain farmers. Golo notes "very cheap compared to EU, friendly people" and "surprisingly large uninhabited areas by European standards."

community.explanation: The regional Balkan gravel scene draws 160 riders including elite talent like Tour Divide winner Justinas Leveika and Jenny Tough. Golo describes excellent "price/performance ratio" with "apartments from 18 euros upwards" fostering an accessible community atmosphere.

field_depth.explanation: While elite riders like Valerio Cecchi and Jochen Böhringer participate in regional Balkan events, the specific competitive depth for this 65-mile format remains unclear. The broader Trans Balkan Race attracts international talent but over vastly different distances. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100.

value.explanation: Following regional pricing at €350, this delivers solid value for cross-border European gravel racing. Golo emphasizes the economic advantage: "very cheap compared to EU" with quality accommodation from "18 euros upwards" keeping total costs reasonable.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs €50-80. International travel to Slovenia/Croatia plus cross-border logistics create the main expense burden. Elite setups like Valerio Cecchi's custom Miss Grape bags and dynamo lighting systems suggest equipment costs can escalate, though basic participation remains accessible. Higher total cost than Badlands.

citations.label: escapecollective.com: A Winning Trek That Suggests Full Suspension Gravel Bikes...
bikepacking.com: Rigs Of The 2025 Trans Balkan Race
biketour-global.de: My Next Adventure Trans Balkan Race 2024
biketour-global.de: Bikeanalytics Evaluation Of The Trans Balkan Race 2025 Bikes
bombtrack.com: Rigs Of The 2025 Trans Balkan Race

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: The Balkans: A gravel cycling film by More Stories Tomorrow.
videos.description:
The Balkans, is More Stories Tomorrow's second adventure together,  an exploration of lands less travelled. Three friends, three countries and 500km of some of South Eastern Europes most under appreciated gems.
 
Our goal with this film was to capture, concentrate and bottle-up the unique fun and friendship that's formed through adventure, in the hope with sharing it with as many people as possible.

morestoriestomorrow.com

Edited by Tom Hardies, filmed by Lawrence Carpenter and Tom Hardies. 

Had a cycling accident? Check out CAMS here: https://c-ams.co.uk/
-Insta360 camera affiliate link: https://www.insta360.com/sal/one_rs?i...

Social Media: 
INSTAGRAM: https://www.instagram.com/bikerlawrence
FACEBOOK: https://www.facebook.com/bikerlawrence​
TWITTER: https://www.twitter.com/bikerlawrence​
STRAVA: https://www.strava.com/athletes/260677​
 
Music: 2 songs 
Elevate your videos with record-label quality music from MusicBed here:   http://share.mscbd.fm/bikerlawrence

videos.curation_reason: High-production cinematic gravel cycling adventure through the Balkans with excellent view count and authentic riding experience.

videos.title: Trans Dinarica Part 1: Slovenia & Croatia : Balkans Bike Packing Tour
videos.description:
I spent six weeks from the end of August to early October following the Trans Dinarica bike packing route through the eight Balkan countries. 
I started by flying into Ljubljana, Slovenia and generally following the whole route and finished by doing a little bit extra in order to finish at the coast at Split, Croatia.
I need to say that I did deviate from the main route a few times during the ride but I estimate that I followed it about 80% of the time.
Excellent route and experience....very hilly as expected.

videos.curation_reason: Recent first-person bikepacking experience covering the Trans Dinarica route through Slovenia and Croatia with detailed terrain insights.

videos.title: Croatia & Slovenia Bike Tour Video | Backroads
videos.description:
Slovenia and Croatia may be small (just over 6 million people between them), but natural beauty, vibrant culture and rich history abound in these two gorgeous countries. From the snowcapped peaks of Slovenia’s Julian Alps to the crystalline waters of the Adriatic Sea along Croatia’s renowned shimmering coastline, plus the verdant fields and forests of the countryside in between, spectacular vistas await at every turn. Need more convincing? Enjoy this video shot on our Croatia & Slovenia Bike Tour! 

Here are all the trip details: https://backroadsgo.com/2OJGPdY
videos.transcript:
[Music]
Sylvania Croatia have been unbelievable
I had no idea how gorgeous both
countries have been until now we get to
see Lake Bled and the turquoise blue
waters and cathedral descending into
Alpine villages you know we're along the
shores of the Adriatic which is just
stunning
one of the highlights would be at this

there she go into these just remarkable
viewpoints and into these valleys that
are out of a storybook

videos.title: What's it like to cycle the Western Balkans? Presenting the Trans Dinarica (teaser)
videos.description:
The Trans Dinarica — Europe’s last great adventure — is the first and only cycle route to connect all eight countries of the Western Balkans. The route, which focuses on bicycle touring along quiet roads and packed-gravel forest paths, links Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, North Macedonia, Kosovo, and Serbia.

The Trans Dinarica makes a priority of visiting national parks, UNESCO sites, traditional communities, villages through the Dinaric Alps and Shar Mountains, and diverse cultural locales. An Epic Adventure across the Western Balkans. Ready in 2024.

Sign up on www.transdinarica.com for more info and for navigational packages.

videos.title: BREATHTAKING BALKANS - EPISODE 01 -  TET SLOVENIA / CROATIA
videos.description:
This is it, the big one, the Very Grand Tour of the Breathtaking Balkans. In June 2024, 7 friends drove to the Balkans to ride some of the most spectacular and challenging roads of the Trans Euro Trail. 

An attempt to find and search for the wild, search for the roughest tracks, the steepest climbs, the roughest terrain, in short one of the biggest challenges the Trans Euro Trail has to offer. With one reward in mind. To get to ride in landscape and scenery that will have you say, over and over again, THIS is the most amazing place I’ve ever ridden my motorbike.

Follow us on a journey of a lifetime, 3000 km through 4 countries in The Breathtaking Balkans, a Grand Tour of the Trans Euro Trail

It’s a story told, about riding your motorcycle, about friendship, about overcoming fear and challenges together, and about living out your dreams.

Thank you Ingvar, Jake, Johannes, Stefan and Sven for an unforgettable journey. 

Episode 01
We take off from Sweden, Norway and Denmark by car and travel for 20 hours to Slovenia. Here we embark on the first leg of the 3000km through the Balkans and ride the Trans Euro Trail in Slovenia and Croatia. The weather quickly becomes a surprising factor of the ride, progress is slower than expected, but it becomes more an adventure because of it. 

Supported by @twinpegs8360  and @Stegraio 

Special thanks to;
Trans Euro Trail https://transeurotrail.org/

Thank you to  
@REVITsport  @CardoSystemsGlobal @tcxboots1  @AraiHelmetEurope @GoProMX @yamahamotoreu @CanonEurope 
not in any affiliation with this video or sponsorships, but we couldn't have done it without you.

Riding gear;

Saddlebags from @kriega8589  - OS Base 18L and 30L
Jacket from @REVITsport  - H2O Component
Protective vest from Rev’it - Proteus
Trousers from Hallman Racing by Thor
Boots from Alpine Stars - Tech 7 Drystar
Helmet from Arai - Tour XD4
Goggles from 100pct - Barstow Deus X Machina
Gloves from Rev’it - Dirt 3
Camera backpack from LowePro - Tactic 350

videos.curation_reason: High-quality recent production showing challenging Trans Euro Trail terrain through Slovenia and Croatia with good view count.

quotes.text: So I decided to take the off-road version of the route. The off-road track is pretty tough, so I'm going to probably drop back onto it because I'm having to push some of the hills already and it's pretty hard going.
The first big climb of the trip. It's been a long one. Most of it was about 4%. In the last K and a half, it's been around 10% on the switchbacks.

Soon as we come over the top we descend maybe 2 or 3K just as the sun's coming down and everything changes just changes to like Farmland the buildings change for like these concrete blocks everything is just completely different.

key_challenges.name: Tunnel section
key_challenges.description: Riders describe going through a tunnel with potentially livestock inside as one of the most frightening experiences. One rider called it 'top five of most scary in my life' though they found it empty when they went through.

key_challenges.name: Mountain mechanicals
key_challenges.description: Riders got separated due to mechanical issues in the mountains, with one rider experiencing tire problems that caused delays and concern from the group.

terrain_notes.text: The gravel is described as 'very rough' and demanding. The route includes rolling gravel with some asphalt sections, but is mostly gravel terrain.
Northern Slovenia has lots of tarmac and big hard packed gravel roads, while southern sections had unexpected challenging bits that caught riders off guard.

race_day_tips.text: Carry extra drinks for teammates who might have mechanical issues, as riders can get separated in the mountains and lose time.

additional_quotes.text: We start by climbing out of the bustling Bay of cotor and once we leave the adventure really begins
20 hours in the car man I can't feel my legs ready to race
It's the Journey of the destination a cliche you would have heard a thousand times before but as you know cliches exist because they're true

rider_intel.search_text: The Balkan Gravel race takes riders through challenging terrain across Slovenia and Croatia, featuring demanding and dynamic rolling gravel with some asphalt sections. Riders describe the gravel as very rough and the conditions as very hot. Key challenges include a frightening tunnel section that riders warn about, and mountain terrain where mechanical issues can separate groups and cause significant delays. The northern Slovenia sections feature hard packed gravel roads and tarmac, while southern areas contain unexpected challenging terrain. The route climbs out of the Bay of Kotor and passes through dramatically changing landscapes from bustling areas to remote farmland. Weather conditions have been described as perfect despite expectations of horrible weather, though the heat presents a significant challenge for riders tackling this demanding course through the breathtaking but unforgiving Balkan mountains.

photos.alt: First-person view from motorcycle or ATV navigating through dense forest trail with ferns and equipment visible - Balkan Gravel - Slovenia/Croatia
Two people walking along grassy lakeside path with small boat moored at peaceful forest lake - Balkan Gravel - Slovenia/Croatia
Motorcyclists riding on dirt road through rolling hills and forest landscape in countryside setting - Balkan Gravel - Slovenia/Croatia
Course preview from Balkan Gravel race footage
